title.narrative: URU/13/G32 Environmental Sound Life-Cycle Management of

description.narrative: URU/13/G32 Environmental Sound Life-Cycle Management of Mercury Containing Products And Their Wastes. Gestión Ambientalmente Adecuada del Ciclo de Vida de los Productos que contienen Mercurio y sus Desechos..

title.narrative: URU/13/G32 Environmental Sound Life-Cycle Management of
URU/13/G32 Environmental Sound Life-Cycle Management of
URU/13/G32 Environmental Sound Life-Cycle Management of

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new partnership mechanisms with funding for sustainable management solutions of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste at national and/or sub-national level

URU/13/G32 Environmental Sound Life-Cycle Management of Mercury Containing Products And Their Wastes. Gestión Ambientalmente Adecuada del Ciclo de Vida de los Productos que contienen Mercurio y sus Desechos..
Energy - policy, planning and administration

The objective of the project is protect human health and the environment from Mercury releases originating from the intentional use of mercury in products and the unsound management and disposal of such products
No of Hgcontaining medical devices and energy saving light sources decontaminated and disposed of within the project period 2014 2017

comment.narrative: In Uruguay there are no adequate storage decontamination and disposal solutions in place for Mercury containing product waste Most of such wastes are disposed of along with regular household waste

In total the project expects to recover 330 kg of Mercury as a direct outcome of the projects implementation In addition changed practices will also result in sustained Mercury reductions of approximately 725 kg Hgyear

The project has setup a logistics technology and business model expert team LTBM which works under the guidance of the project coordinator and in close collaboration with all projects stakeholders Scientific and Technological Pando Park and Pole PCTP National Administration of Power Plants and Energy Transmission UTE and National Environment Directorate DINAMA
In April a first field visit took place in order to quantify the main existing Hgwaste storage facilities Pereira Rossell Hospital ASSE LATU identify the capacity and treatment process performed by companies authorized by DINAMA to work with this waste Triex and Márgenes del Rio and review existing initiatives for collection MIEM IMM tank lighting CIU and UTE lamps collection campaign in order to remove 1200000 waste lamps
A first draft of the mercury waste collection transportation treatment and disposal solution was produced at the end of June

description.narrative: Quantity kg of elemental Hg safeguarded which has been recovered from the decontamination process

comment.narrative: If not disposed of such wastes are kept in inappropriate interim storage locations
Elemental Hg recovered from treatmentdecontamination has been safely stored at the ChlorAlkali facility exported to a longterm storage facility or immobilized using appropriate technologies
Not applicable to this reporting period This activity is expected to take place once the treatment facility is in operation

description.narrative: Safe decontamination options for Mercury containing products established

comment.narrative: n the whole of Uruguay there are no options for the sound decontamination storage or disposal of Mercury containing products
Treatment facility constructed inline with Basel Convention guidelines and in compliance with national regulations

Technical specifications for the international bidding process of the treatment facility which is expected to be launched in September 2015 are being developed by the international expert in close coordination with the project team
An agreement was held with the Scientific and Technological Pando Park to determine the location of the treatment facility The architectural project is being developed by technical experts from the Scientific and Technological Pando Park and Pole

description.narrative: Development of environmentally sound schemes and business models for the collection treatment and disposal of mercury wastes
Business models and cost recovery arrangements CRA for the collection transport temporary storage and treatment of different types of Hg wastes operational and financially sustainable

comment.narrative: There are no financial mechanisms in place to cover the costs for the LCM of Hg containing lamps CFLs and tubes
Business plan for the collection transport temporary storage and treatment of different types of Hg wastes finalized
The business plan is being developed by the business model expert and is expected to be presented on October for validation on November 2015

description.narrative: Mercury releases from priority sectors reduced and segregated Hg containing waste streams augmented

comment.narrative: Current stockpiles underestimated are described in the projects baseline and on page 8 footnote 932
Waste management committees operationalized in each model facility

The Health Institutions Project partners the Ministry of Public Health and ASSE are in the process of selecting 13 model institutions
A call for applicants for a Management Committee Consultant to work at the Model Health Facilities is on going The Consultant will be responsible for i joining the management committee if existing or promoting its formation ii promoting the sessions of the Management Committee iii developing guidelines for mercury waste management at healthcare facilities iv looking for mechanisms to legitimize the management committee

description.narrative: Number of private sector operators model healthcare facilities and PCTP staff capacitated in best practices related to collection storage treatment of Hg containing products and longterm safe storage of elemental Mercury as well as the use of costeffective Hgfree or lowMercury content alternatives if applicable

comment.narrative: Some model facilities have waste management committees in place a few of the HCFs but most do not
Hg baseline assessments procurement use management disposal storage etc completed for each model facility
Not applicable until the consultant is hired and the model institutions have been selected as these assessments are part of hisher responsibility

description.narrative: Monitoring adaptive feedback outreach and evaluation
Number of high quality monitoring and evaluation documents prepared during project implementation

comment.narrative: No documents in baseline situation
4 Quarterly Operational Reports submitted to UNDP each year

A monthly report is sent to project partner institutions MSP ASSE CIAT PCTP AOULATU UTE AUCI PNUD and DINAMA
On June 2015 the project implementation report covering the period since the project launch in October 2014 was presented at a Steering Committee Meeting

description.narrative: Strengthen the regulatory and policy framework to allow for lifecycle management of mercury containing products and their wastes Equivalent to activity in ATLAS
Improved adherence to the sound collection temp storage and treatment of products containing mercury in particular project partners and model facilities

comment.narrative: Annexes of the BC have been transposed in the Hazardous Waste Law law 172201999 which refers in specific to hazardous waste streams including waste containing mercury and regulates storage transportation and disposal of hazardous waste including Hg containing products

Guidelines and legal provisions with respect to the sound collection temp storage and treatment of products containing mercury and the storage of elemental mercury will be reviewed based on int best practices Basel Convention and reviseddeveloped if necessary

The guidelines and the description of the regulatory framework with respect to collection storage treatment and disposal system are being developed by the LTBM team and are expected to be presented at a workshop to be held in December 2015

description.narrative: National Extended Producer Responsibility EPR policy and regulations for mercury containing products adopted and introduced

comment.narrative: There are no financial mechanisms in place that promote the LCM of Hg containing lamps CFLs and tubes

EPR for Hgcontaining lamps established as a tool to provide for the financial resources necessary to cover operational costs of the collection interim storage decontamination and disposal of Hgcontaining lamps costs

The LTBM team is currently developing the planapproach for the waste mercury collection transportation treatment and disposal system which includes technical requirements a business plan and logistical requirements and using the EPR as a tool
Terms of reference for the hiring of a legal expert to support the National Environment Directorate DINAMA in the drafting of the EPR policy and regulations are being developed for publication at end of July 2015

description.narrative: Strengthened policy and regulatory framework to enable the phaseoutdown of mercury containing products and encourage Hgfree or lower level Hg products

comment.narrative: There are no restrictions on the importation of high Hgcontent lamps CFLs tubes or Hgcontaining medical devices

EU RoHS directives for lighting products transposed into national regulations through a degree restricting importation of high Hg content lamps MSP degree prescribing a phased approachtotal phaseout for the use of Hgcontaining devices at Healthcare facility level developed
An agreement was reached with MSP for the development of this regulation by the Ministrys legal advisers during the second semester of 2015

description.narrative: Strengthening national and regional awareness on the Sound LifeCycle Management of Mercury containing products as well as associated health hazards resulting from mismanagement
Awareness on LCM of Mercury containing products increased among project stakeholders the general public and countries at regional and global level

comment.narrative: BCCC LAC has a website which it uses for information dissemination BCCC LAC also leads a network of national Basel Convention Centers through which information on hazardous waste management can be disseminated
Website and Facebook page developed and regularly updated English and Spanish

An agreement was reached with the Basel Convention Coordinating Centre BCCC to spread Project information through its website
Another agreement was reached with DINAMA for the development of a Project Websitein coordination with BCCC

description.narrative: National capacity to monitor Mercury levels in populations strengthened

comment.narrative: As part of a CIATUSAID pilot project 2006 biomonitoring of Mercury levels in healthcare staff was undertaken by CIATs poison control center at a model facility
Technical specifications for PCTPCIAT biomonitoring laboratory equipment prepared

The technical specifications for PCTPCIAT biomonitoring laboratory equipment were prepared in coordination with the PCTP technical experts The international bidding for procurement of the laboratory equipment was launched in march 2015

description.narrative: Strengthening technical capacity and infrastructure for the treatment and storage medium and long term of Mercury containing wastes
Intermediate Hg storage options established and longterm storage options identified

comment.narrative: In the whole of Uruguay there are no safe options for the sound interim storage of Mercury containing productswastes or the longterm storage of elemental Mercury
Assessment for shortterm interim and longterm storage and disposal options completed
Shortterm interim and longterm storage facilities are being identified and designed as part of the national plan on the LCM of products containing mercury and mercury wasteswastes

description.narrative: Technology to treat collected Hg containing product waste operational

comment.narrative: In the whole of Uruguay there are no options for the treatment of Mercury containing products
Technical specifications for the treatment facility inline with Basel Convention guidelines and in compliance with national regulations developed
Draft Technical specifications for the international bidding process of the treatment facility are being developed by the international expert in close coordination with the project team

title.narrative: URU/13/G35 Fortalecimiento de la efectividad del Sistema
URU/13/G35 Fortalecimiento de la efectividad del Sistema
URU/13/G35 Fortalecimiento de la efectividad del Sistema

description.narrative: URU/13/G35 Fortalecimiento de la efectividad del Sistema Nacional de Áreas Protegidas incluyendo el enfoque de paisaje en la gestión”.
The Uruguayan Protected Areas System incorporates a landscape approach to management strengthening the effectiveness of PAs as nuclei for the conservation of globally important species and ecosystems
Area and condition as measured by the Pasture Conservation Index ICP of natural pasture habitat for important bird species in PAs and surrounding areas

comment.narrative:
Area ha under natural pasture by site
Farrapos Mafalda 13384 ha
Queguay 111225 ha
Lunarejo Laureles 230369 ha
Rocha Garzón 104695 ha
Total 459673 ha
No net loss in area or condition of natural pastures in the target areas
1 PRUEBA

description.narrative: Area and condition of other natural ecosystems by site

comment.narrative:
Canyon forest
Queguay 295 ha
Lunarejo Laureles 38914 ha
Rocha Garzón 25280 ha
Total 64489 ha
Gallery forest
Farrapos Mafalda 7919 ha
Queguay 4891 ha
Lunarejo Laureles 13469 ha
Rocha Garzón 5818 ha
Total 32097 ha
Park forest
Farrapos Mafalda 3868 ha
Queguay 10849 ha
Lunarejo Laureles 38914 ha
Total 53631 ha
Psammophyll forest
Rocha Garzón 210 ha
Wetlandsreedbeds
Farrapos Mafalda 8682 ha
Queguay 2538 ha
Rocha Garzón 7497 ha
Total 18717 ha
No net loss in area or condition of each ecosystem

The base line for this indicator was estimated using low resolution satellite images However the project partially supported the acquisition of highresolution satellite images on 2015 This allowed the enforcement of a new and more detailed ecosystem surface measurement methodology in broad territories which will be the data source for various indicators to be included in the Monitoring and Evaluation System that is being designed It was considered as highly convenient to use the same data source for the calculation of various indicators Therefore a new base line was generated for this indicator See Annex Methodological Reference for logic framework indicators Anexo Referencia metodológica para indicadores del marco logico
To date the indicator was applied in Tacuarembó department target zone Northern Canyons in Río Negro department target zone Western Littoral and in the entire target zone Coastal lagoons For the rest of North Canyon Rivera the image processing is yet to be performed and for the area Montes del Queguay of Western Littoral images are to be acquired Complete results will be available towards the end of 2015 The chart below presents the results obtained on June 2015 The indicator will be calculated again on 2018
New base line
Priority Ecosystem
Surface in hectares per target area Discrimination of total area per type of forest is still in process

Canyon Gallery and Park Forest 36433

description.narrative: Reductions in the incidence of IAS in PAs

comment.narrative:
Incidence of Gleditsia triachanthos in Farrapos
140 49 ha
4061 40 ha
61100 110 ha

Incidence of Gleditsia triachanthos in Farrapos
140 49 ha
4061 80 ha
61100 70 ha

In 2014 approximately 600 ha of Esteros de Farrapos protected area were estimated to have incidence of invasive species Aiming to update the baseline new highresolution satellite images were acquired and a new methodology to estimate the indicator was proposed See Anexo Referencia metodológica para indicadores del marco lógico Base line values per coverage level are being adjusted during 2015 Afterwards the program for controlling invasive species will begin

description.narrative: Protected area management integrated with adjacent landscapes

Area of forestry properties where design and management of setasides incorporate landscapewide BD considerations such as the size and spatial configuration of pasture areas in relation to vertical barriers such as forestry plantations and the spatial configuration condition and flowering seeding status of pasture grasses which determine the value of the setasides for pasture birds

comment.narrative: 188688ha of forestry plantation properties in target landscapes of which an estimated 15 is setasides 28303ha all of which are planned and managed on individual basis
50 of setasides 14152ha in forestry plantations in target landscapes are planned and managed in accordance with landscapewide considerations

SNAP participated with forestry producers and the academic sector in the cycle of workshops organized by the University of the Republic aimed to analyze the new exigencies of the standard FSC and identify new indicators for the national standard In addition SNAP and the Society of Forest Producers started the negotiations for the definition of a national protocol to identify areas of high value of conservation in forest plantations and the agreement on criteria for planning and management in such zones of conservation Indicator will be measured once the criteria for planning and management are agreed

description.narrative: Areas with public use and tourism plans in accordance with the national guidelines on tourism in protected areas currently being prepared

comment.narrative: None as the guidelines are still under preparation
To be determined

On August 2014 the Guidelines for Public Use in Protected Areas was approved by MINTUR and MVOTMA and the UNIT Rule for Sustainable Tourism in Protected Area was published
On June 2015 jointly with METT evaluation the planning process for the application of the tool Monitoring effectiveness of the public use foreknown on the guidelines has begun in order to establish the indicators baseline

description.narrative: Effectiveness of mechanisms for stakeholder participation in planning and management

comment.narrative: CAEs exist in all three target PAs declared to date with broad participation but no mechanisms for feedback or evaluation of effectiveness and satisfaction

All 7 PAs to be included in the project have CAEs with functioning mechanisms for feedback and evaluation of effectiveness and satisfaction and CAEs receive consistent positive rating from stakeholder participants

The indicator will be measured towards the ending of 2015 This years goal all AP entered to SNAP prior to 2014 have formalized CAE See Annex Referencia metodológica para medición de indicadores del marco lógico The introduction of mechanisms for feedback and evaluation of the effectiveness and performance of the CAEs is planned for the year 2016

description.narrative: Increase in METT scores in 7 PAs covering 214336ha

comment.narrative:
Farrapos 50
Lunarejo 45
Laureles Cañas 11
Rocha 45
Garzón 11
Queguay 24
Mafalda 60

Farrapos 83
Lunarejo 76
LaurelesCañas 46
Rocha 80
Garzón 46
Queguay 49
Mafalda 75
The process of planning for the application of METT started in July 2015 Results will be available on November 2015

description.narrative: Levels of staff assignment in Departmental governments for supporting integration of PA management with land use planning

comment.narrative: 3 of the 6 Departmental Governments covering the target areas have staff with specific responsibilities for planning and management of rural areas including those in or adjoining PAs

All 6 of the Departmental Governments covering the target areas Río Negro Paysandú Maldonado Rocha Rivera and Tacuarembó have staff with specific responsibilities for planning and management of rural areas including those in or adjoining PAs

Due to the change in departmental authorities on 2015 a new baseline will be created according to new situation on the second half of the year However the joint working agenda agreed with DINOT includes qualification training and technology transfer to departmental governments in order to support and promote the inclusion of more trained personnel in rural spatial planning processes

description.narrative: Number of Departmentallevel zoning plans that make specific reference to PAs and their areas of influence

comment.narrative:
Coastal Lagoons
Coastal Lagoons Local Plan covering Rocha and Garzón lagoons
Western Littoral
Guichón MicroRegion Local Plan for Zoning and Sustainable Development covering Montes de Queguay

Coastal Lagoons
Coastal Lagoons Local Plan covering Rocha and Garzón
Western Littoral
Guichón MicroRegion Local Plan
Departmental zoning plan covering Farrapos
Northern Canyons
Departmental Zoning Plans for Rivera and Tacuarembó covering Lunarejo and Laureles Cañas

In 2014 the methodological process to measure this indicator was developed and the baseline created from 8 spatial plans approved and linked to the target zones 6 have some sort of reference to SNAP Indicators results for 2014 are Western littoral 25 North Canyons 0 Coastal lagoon 39 Total target areas 275 max 6 See Annex Referencia metodológica para medición de indicadores del marco lógico
In this period SNAP participated in the Strategic Environmental Evaluation carried out by DINAMA of Department Spatial Planning Guidelines Directrices Departamentales de Ordenamiento Territorial of Tacuarembó and Rio Negro As result both instruments incorporate specific contributions for including the landscape approach in spatial planning for conservation in target zones territories The indicator will be measured again in 2016

description.narrative: System level Protected Area frameworks consolidated to adopt the landscape approach
Amount of resources from Protected Area Fund received by SNAP

comment.narrative: Annual Operating Plan 2015 does not prioritize action lines regarding this objective The indicator will be measured annually from 2016

description.narrative: Area of land in Laureles Cañas and Queguay with tax exemptions due to native forest cover

comment.narrative: None of the 6790ha native forest in Laureles and Queguay is declared for tax exemption
4074ha 60 of the native forest in Laureles and Queguay is declared for tax exemption

Required modifications for the agreement between MGAP and DINAMA associated to the native forest are being discussed in order to extend its enforcement in Laureles Cañas that is not a protected area registered in SNAP and therefore it is kept outside the agreement
The indicator will be measured annually from 2016

description.narrative: Area of land with tax exemptions due to inclusion in SNAP

comment.narrative: 0ha

Lunarejo 3321ha
Laguna de Rocha 707ha

A proposal to exclude the payment of the rural real estate tax land tax collected by local government to rural properties located in areas of minimum low or medium intervention regarding the Management Plan of a protected area was put forward for inclusion in the National Budget Law
The indicator will be measured annually from 2016

of DINAMA staff with capacities for interaction with landscape level actors and processes target values to be quantified on the basis of staff assessment at project start

Institutionalized agreement in reference to criteria values and guidelines regarding biodiversity in planning process and environmental regulation did not exist until 2014 During 2015 a joint working agenda SNAPBiodiversity DivisionDINOT was agreed aimed to promote biodiversity and conservation mainstreaming in spatial planning tools Planned activities under this agreement include among others qualification training for DINOT and DINAMA staff and departmental technical staff and the update of the Guidelines for Spatial Planning published by DINOT in 2013
The indicator will be measured in 2016 and 2018 after one year of joint agenda approval and implementation See Anexo Referencia metodológica para medición de indicadores del marco lógico

description.narrative: Reduction in financial gap for SNAP

comment.narrative: Financial gap for SNAP as a whole 30 999000
20 reduction in financial gap for SNAP as a whole to 24 800000

During 2015 SNAPs budget was arranged for its inclusion in the fiveyear MVOTMA 20162020 budget Human resources and necessary founds for a basic management of the System were estimated taking into consideration the foreknown evolution of the SNAP physical network As well a proposal of tax incentives for privates to donate to the Protected Areas Fund was put forward for consideration of the parliament The fiveyear budget will be approved by the parliament on the last trimester of this year If the proposal is approved an additional source of funds may be available to finance the System
Results from these actions could be appreciated from 2016 on The indicator will be measured in 2016 and 2018

The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new partnership mechanisms with funding for sustainable management solutions of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste at national and/or sub-national level

El presente proyecto tiene como propósito contribuir al fortalecimiento de la DINAGUA del MVOTMA en lo que refiere a sus cometidos de elaborar las políticas que propendan a la universalización del acceso al saneamiento
